awd_titl_txt: Singular Limits and Gradient Flows: Analysis and Numerics
awd_abstract_narration:
Minimization of potential energy characterizes phenomena throughout the natural world.  In certain systems, known as gradient flows, the principle of minimizing potential energy as quickly as possible completely determines the system's behavior.  Examples include models of vortices in superconductors and of cells communicating via chemical signals.  The present project will study gradient flows arising in physics, biology, and engineering through a unified approach combining mathematical analysis and numerical simulation.  This research will be pursued in collaboration with undergraduate and graduate students.

The gradient flow systems at the heart of the present research are nonlinear systems involving nonlocal interactions, which arise not only in the examples mentioned previously, but also in robotic control algorithms, geometric shape optimization, and quantum information theory.  These gradient flows do not satisfy traditional convexity assumptions of the calculus of variations, and techniques from partial differential equations have been unable to compensate for these limitations in the general theory.  This project aims to overcome these gaps through the development of more general notions of convexity, well-posedness results that link dynamics and asymptotic behavior, and novel spatial and temporal discretizations of the gradient flow problem.  Two key motivating questions are singular limits of gradient flows: (1) the nonlocal approximation of diffusion and (2) the slow diffusion limit, a generalization of the mesa problem.  In both cases, convexity and regularity deteriorate in the limit, bringing into focus the limitations of the existing theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past twenty years, models inspired by statistical mechanics have surged in importance throughout the sciences. Across disciplines and applications, scientists are viewing systems in terms of particle interactions, where the notion of particle spans from a cell in a petri dish, to an infinitesimal element in a fluid, a robot in a fleet, or a computational node in an algorithm. When the number of particles is large, the classical mathematical and computational approaches, which consider each particle individually, are no longer feasible: the complexity of individual interactions obscures the overall dynamics and the cost of computational simulation is prohibitive. Because of this, scientists are moving beyond the classical discrete approach to embrace the continuum perspective: instead of tracking the behavior of each individual particle, scientists instead consider the behavior of the density of particles at a given location, recasting their models into the framework of partial differential equations. Theoretically, this perspective extracts the key features of the dynamics and enables predictions that are robust as the number of particles fluctuates. Computationally, it provides an efficient way to study a system?s behavior, even for large numbers of particles. 

However, there is a tradeoff: the price paid for the clarity of the continuum description is that the problem is no longer framed in terms of cells interacting in a finite dimensional space or a fully discrete algorithm executing finitely many steps, but in terms of densities evolving in an infinite dimensional space. The space of densities inherits a geometric structure from the particle system, but geometric surprises can occur in the continuum limit?in the case of cells communicating via chemical signals, one passes from particles moving in the flat plane of the petri dish to densities evolving in positively curved Wasserstein space. It is no longer clear in what regimes one can trust the models to give reasonable predictions. For example, is the model stable under perturbations of the initial data, or, in the case of training an artificial neural network, could a slight change in the initial values of the training parameters completely distort the resulting predictions? 

Over the course of the grant, the PI used the gradient flow perspective and optimal transport to study the mathematical properties of models arising throughout the applied sciences and to develop improved methods for their computational simulation. Gradient flows are ubiquitous, arising whenever dynamics emerge from a system?s tendency to dissipate energy: for example, when a ball rolls down a hill to dissipate potential energy or a neural network is trained to dissipate a loss functional. Likewise, optimal transport is a natural tool to study particle systems. As originally posed by Gaspard Monge, the optimal transport problem asks how to rearrange one pile of dirt to look like another, using the least amount of effort. As the concept of ?moving around dirt? has been abstracted to ?moving around particles,? optimal transport has had an enormous impact on pure mathematics, applied mathematics, and machine learning. 

The main mathematical achievements of the funded research were advancements in the mathematical theory of gradient flows; the development and analysis of methods for computer simulation of gradient flows; and advances at the interface of optimal transport and machine learning, including application of optimal transport methods to machine learning problems in particle physics.The grant has also supported the PI's mentoring and outreach work, aimed at improving the retention of underrepresented groups in mathematics and communicating mathematics to a broad scientific audience.
